Here's a interesting story that explains death in the first person. May 17, 2015 I died of a massive heart attack. For me it was a dreamless sleep. No pain even though I was electricuted 5 different times I never felt anything. 8 days later in a CCU the doctors told my kids that it was over they could do no more. Now (granted my son told me all this stuff after.) My kids were to return in the morning at 8 am and say good bye. The staff would then stop the machines keeping me alive. That night or morning I don't know, but I woke up, I felt the tube in my mouth and began to chew on it, my chewing set off the alarm and the nurse came in to the dark room turned on the light and saw me looking at him. It sounded to me far away but he yelled He's alive. From that point forward I felt everything that had been done to me. Coming back is the same as being born, nothing works, I had to relearn my life, walk, talk, just like a baby, it's been 5 years and I feel great, 1 big stent in the front of my heart fixed me. An interesting thing to point out is that you die constantly, technically speaking. The physical matter that makes up your body breaks down and is completely replaced very quickly. Granted it might be the same type of matter, but not that exact matter. Although your body is efficient at recycling matter, it's an immutable law of nature that no system is 100% efficient. Likewise, your consciousness is just information and signals between your neurons, so as your mental state changes significantly, you as an abstract being die too. The ideas that make you you change all the time, and if they don't then that's when you have the most problems. You now and you 10 years from now will be, for all practical purposes, completely different people.

That's just entropy; all systems break down over time. The illusion of "living" comes from us being able to repair ourselves faster than we break down, both from a physical and mental perspective. Evolution, then, is really just the process of systems becoming better at repairing themselves through trial and error.

Clearly the great Seventeenth Century English scholar and metaphysical poet JOHN DONNE would never agree with Epicurus' outlook on death, given his famous (and my all-time favorite) sonnet "Death, be not proud":

Death, be not proud, though some have called thee
Mighty and dreadful, for thou art not so;
For those whom thou think'st thou dost overthrow
Die not, poor Death, nor yet canst thou kill me.
From rest and sleep, which but thy pictures be,
Much pleasure; then from thee much more must flow,
And soonest our best men with thee do go,
Rest of their bones, and soul's delivery.
Thou art slave to fate, chance, kings, and desperate men,
And dost with poison, war, and sickness dwell,
And poppy or charms can make us sleep as well
And better than thy stroke; why swell'st thou then?
One short sleep past, we wake eternally
And death shall be no more; Death, thou shalt die.

Frankly, the vast majority of what those ancient philosophers said should be rejected given what we know about the immeasurable complexity of living cells. No natural force could possibly have brought together such vast complexity out from randomness and chaos. Nobody walks along the beach and comes upon words written in the sand, "Patty, I love you," and claims, "Oh look what the waves created..." They certainly don't claim while driving their car, "Oh, I'm so glad nature created this automobile for me to drive," which is vastly LESS complex than living cells and a brain that can reason, recognize ethics and morality. We are creatures of life. We ARE our very consciousness. Therefore, our #1 priority as beings of consciousness is to ensure that that consciousness continues. Life LIVES to ensure that life CONTINUES, the same way that existence needs to survive in order to BE existence, and therefore cannot end. However, that doesn't mean that those living a painful existence is better. What's good to us is what is good during life, and since the loss of life would end it, whether or not death is good really depends on how you feel about your life. Imagine a world in which you could CHOOSE whether or not you want to die. When you were ready, you could leave, and until then, you could keep doing what you like. However, going further in depth, the total annihilation of an entire existence is the most horrible thing possible - due to fact that existence exists to continue its existence - and as such total oblivion is never a good thing. In the perfect world, whether or not death occurs would be CONTROLLED by the entity that wished to die. Thank you for your time.

For me my fear of death is entirely that sense of not knowing, which is odd because I know what it's like to not be conscious and as such I can have a rough grasp of what death would be like. When I was much younger I needed dental surgery to remove deeply rooted canine teeth so that my adult incisors would be able to grow in properly, at the time I was naive. I was told that the anesthetic gas could cause specific dreams, aka if you pick the 'green' cannister you will dream of soccer, no doubt to make it less scarier than 'you're not going to exist for the next 3 hours' that it really was. My memory of it is still vivid, I could tell the gas wasn't air, it was off, and within a matter of moments my eyes fell shut and then nothing, next thing I can remember is being carried. Then being awake in the car, and being asked what I wanted to eat.

I don't remember the empty space, there's nothing to remember, it was empty blackness and as such I'm fairly certain that when I die I will have a solid 30 minutes of existential dread. Maybe 4 or 5 minutes of fading consciousness and pain if I am unlucky, perhaps longer if I am really unlucky and shock hasn't set in, after which the long dark will take me.

My philosophy though has always been best described in book metaphors, we are each writing our own story and all our stories are woven together into a single book for each of us. Our books all take place in the same universe, I am but an unmentioned background character in a great many of those books but for my friends and my family I'm a recurring character. They are likewise part of my narrative, and while our books may share chapters they are never written the same, nor is the style similar, it's a different perspective. Death is the ending, it's the final letter or the period or the exclamation mark or whatever else, it's the final touch of pen to paper and with it the book is closed. Some books will be referenced in others even after the ending, their leads wrote about in touching memories, tall tales being woven for strangers, or even published in online articles and spread around the world. But their book is over, those mentions don't change that, no one will ever pick up their book and continue the story for them, and when those books that referenced them are closed as well they cease to be stories and start to become one of many quadrillions of books that lay littered about.

My fear isn't for when my story ends, my fear is for when their story ends, when I can no longer read their pages or recall their authors with that same clarity I can right now. My fear is the day my mother's author steps away and I am left with a lifeless paperback upon the countless other stacks that came before, my fear is the day my brother's novel comes to a close and I am left writing chapters with but brief recollections of previous pages or moments we shared. My fear is the day my story closes and I know I'll never get to know how it all ends, what the climax of the overall story arch actually is.

Dying first would be a blessing as I'd never have to know how my own story progresses without them, but a curse because I'm leaving them to write after I'm gone.

When my book is closed and ink no longer dances over paper I'll cease to be, or maybe I'll join the other authors as I get to sit back and see where it unfolds from there. Maybe I'll get to see my parents again, maybe my dog will be there, maybe my goldfish, maybe my prehistoric fish ancestor will be excited to see his story spawned so many sequels. I don't know what happens after the book is closed, personally I think that's it, that's how my story ends, and it fills me with dread to know that my story will either continue past my relatives and friends or they'll continue past me.

And at the end of the day, when my fingers are weary and my eyes are heavy I'll sleep soundly, but until then my imagination runs wild and I worry about the nightmares that will never come.

Humans continue to have defeatist perspectives on death. Here is a more positive perspective (worth testing further): That 'death' may be a simple problem to overcome. For example, overcoming 'death' could be as simple as moving further from radiation sources (like the sun and the interior of the earth). To test this, you would move a sufficient distance away from the sun and earth's radiation to see what happens (and since you do not know what a 'sufficient' distance is, you must test for that, also).

The point is humans may have accepted the wrong perspectives - such as death being impossible to overcome, or being so complex that it is still a long way off (and you can see how these perspectives are 'defeatist').

When I was a little kid, I was watching Blue's Clues with my father. He and my mother talked about something and I interjected: "What is death?" I assume, that the word fell in their conversation, but I'm not sure. My father told me: "Death is the end of life." That surprised me. I had never considered, that my life would end. So I asked what happens after you die. My parents were both Christians and took me to church, but for some reason my father said, that after our life there is nothing. "Like sitting in an empty room?" "Not quite, there is not even a room." My mind was blown. "Like darkness?" "Not even that." I became worried and asked him, if death would be boring? He said: "You won't be bored there are no feelings. There are no senses. There is no time. You literally can't be unsatisfied, hurt or scared. It will be the same as it was before you were born." After that death itself didn't scare me anymore.

I do appreciate the philosophical ideas behind this discussion, but one major ideology that is not discussed as much is science as a philosophy. We are living creatures, and to remain so we are most deeply instinctively wired to fear death. That is the biggest motivator to avoid death, remain alive and hopefully propagate life either directly through progeny or indirectly through improving conditions for the remainder of life. It requires no great mystery and we can add as many confounding theories to the most obvious and basic, but it remains that the fear discussed predates the urge to seek nourishment, sex and pleasure, all of which fundamentally seek same ultimate goal, life and its improvement.

My thoughts about the afterlife: I do believe there is an afterlife, but it's nothing extreme like various religions have tried to describe. Afterlife is simply your lingering reputation in the real world. People may try to tell stories about you after you died, but the "you" they describe would be nothing but a shadow of the person "you" were. In other words, all of their memories of you would be mere hypothesis on who you actually were. Once your reputation dies (people forget about you), your afterlife ends and the concept of "you" officially decompose into oblivion.

For example, take the late 14th century English monarch, Richard II. He was really just like any other human in life: he had weaknesses and he had strengths, and due to many events and circumstances, he was deposed and killed by his cousin (Henry IV). 200 years later, Shakespeare wrote a play with him as the titular character, and portrayed him as more or less an "empty shell" of a king (long story). This led to many people thinking of Richard as a weak person who just couldn't cut it. According to my proposal, this is Richard II's afterlife. He was turned from a real flesh-and-blood person into a sort of 2 or 2.5 dimensional caricature of the real him. And once this caricature is forgotten, he disappears into oblivion.

Hell, every origin story you've ever read in religion or fiction was brought on by the desire to know about what happened before your birth. Similarly, missing out on what happens after you die is regrettable because that story hasn't been published yet - so, even if you wanted to read about it, you can't.

I don't want them to grieve, I don't want anyone I know to be sad and I do everything I can in life to make them happy. So of course I'm afraid of dying.
Consider the person closest to me, if their dog died, I can be there for them and console them. If I died, I can't do those things. I can't help them through it. I'm sure other people would, but I just don't want anyone I know to have to be sad and hurt on my behalf.

Epicurus is not normally classed as a Stoic.  He believed that morality is reducible to pleasure (good) and pain (bad).  The Stoics on the other hand suggested that morality rests in the practice of the four cardinal virtues (wisdom, justice, courage, temperance).  Thus Stoicism and Epicurianism are two distinct Hellenistic schools of thought.

The part about "you don't mourn not experiencing the past, why do you fear not experiencing the future?" is debatable. The past can still be experienced in some way. You can read about it, watch documentaries, meet people who were there, and all that stuff. You cannot know the future that way, only speculate about possibilities. Additionally, you cannot go to the past. And even if you could build a time machine, it would bring a fuckton of moral quandaries. On the other hand, you can go to the future. You just have to wait and not die. Which is why I believe death is to be feared and fought at every turn. And we have proven already that with modern science we can lengthen our lifespans to some degree. We should not stop until we achieve immortality. Then death will not be inevitable, but just a choice.

I also believe that it is a good idea to build our own "afterlife" since we can't know if there is one. Socrates' version of the afterlife is almost within our grasp, with the digitalisation of minds (which brings its own philosophical debates).

I think the value of death depends on your values and affections of others as well as other people's values and affections of you. Death would be scary if you cherished people and they cherished you, because when you die, you'll never see that person again, and those people would be forever affected by your death. That in itself is scary, knowing that one day, you'll eventually leave behind the people you care about, and/or will affect the people who cared about you, unable to see the effects of your death in others. Of course, this is only if you had both people you care about and people who care about you. If people didn't care about you, death may be more of a relief, knowing that your death didn't cause any unwanted feelings of others, or rather that you could even escape the harshness of life and reality permanently. Of course, there will still be things missed if you cared about someone, even if they didn't care about you. Which comes to my final point, where death truly wouldn't be so dreadful. When you don't care about anyone else. Apathetic. Narcissistic. If you can truly not care about the people affected by your death, and can die with a straight mind, without being concerned about anything else...then maybe death can be peaceful. And if people didn't care about you, either, then all the more can you embrace death with a calm mind.

"If you don't feel some sort of deep sense of loss at what you missed before you were even alive, why should you feel loss at what you'll miss after you die?"

Personally, I would say people generally feel loss at what they'll miss after they die because they won't get to see the final outcome of anything they've experienced in their lifetime. The difference is that they're already living the final outcome of what was accomplished before they were born-- they have the option to easily access basically any part of the world because of what came of the age of exploration and the innovation of the airplane. Sure it would have been cool to have been alive during those times, but it's not as much of a loss when you already have the aftermath of those times.

However, I would argue that it's much more of a loss not to see Mars or other celestial bodies colonized in your lifetime when, currently, we're working on getting to that point, on achieving that result. Dying before seeing the outcome is certainly something to be reasonably mourned.

So in short, living to see the results ultimately holds more importance than living to work toward the results.

So, a couple things.

Fear of death is illogical, but fear of those things that cause death is completely logical, because those things offer a small chance of survival - painful, torturous, horrible survival. I fear getting mauled to death by an angry bear not because it could kill me, but because it could leave me in such a state that I would be asking for death to come. There are much worse things in this world than death, and when someone lies broken and bloody, horribly injured beyond any chance of recovery or any chance to lead a meaningful life afterwards, granting them mercy is perhaps the worst thing you could do to them.

I don't fear having loved ones die because I fear being left out, I fear it because I hate seeing other people I love suffer. Mourning takes a lot out on a person. They get depressed, weary, overly self-critical, and in some situations even attempt suicide. It's a form of self-torture that I would hate seeing anyone go through. What I fear is the suffering of others that I cannot help.

I think it's best to avoid death and treat it as it is a kind of tragedy because we can't assume anything about the afterlife with certainty, so therefore it would be sensible to focus on what life has to offer, and our life is what gives us our rationality which gives us our ability to find value in our existence.

Death deprives us of the ability to find value in the world and be satisfied by our unity with what we value, and this would show that to some extent life is inherently valuable for human beings.

The past and the future are not perceived as equivalent, therefore they are not readily comparable. We lament not experiencing things in the future more than things in the past because of our perception of time. You only fear death because of a leftover in your genes - self-preservation to pass on genetic material. If you're able to rationalize that it's okay not to have children, it's okay to live your life as something more than an animal, then you can realize that there is no point in fearing death. Your anxiety over non-existence and the various myths you invented to soothe that fear is only your body trying to rationalize what it's impulses are telling it, rather than letting your mind define what your body is meant for. Losing your fear of death can be one of the ways toward true self-definition.

THAT BEING SAID - I want to make one thing perfectly clear since this is a public forum - this does NOT make suicide a form of self-definition and losing fear of death. Suicide is a relationship with death that still essentializes death (which is monolithic and simplistic) over life (which has colorful and endlessly fascinating) and you can watch the video for information on why you can still value your life as it's going on. I am in no way condoning suicide. As Hank's brother says in another video, "It's a permanent solution to a temporary problem."

Living things are all imbibed with an inherent fear of death, which is the instinct to survive. Pain itself is a manifestation of that fear of death, as it is the body's response to stimulus it believes, if left untreated or allowed to worsen, will eventually lead to death. People who don't feel pain tend to die for this very reason.

So the overwhelming majority of ways to die are probably going to be extremely painful as the body desperately tries to ward off death, unless it happens while you're already asleep, or it shuts down the nervous system prior to killing you, or the killing blow destroys your brain faster than the brain can register the pain.

So we are justified in fearing death as much as we fear pain, because most of us dislike pain, and pain is inexorably linked with death.

Not to mention that if we truly don't think death is a bad thing, then we wouldn't care about things like murder or accidents or massacres or disasters. Most people are sorely missed when they die, and it's always sad when someone dies truly unloved who no one will miss. For that to happen, a person must spread an enormous amount of suffering in life, or else have already lost everyone they ever knew in their lives, and both scenarios are tragedies in and of themselves

The problem with all arguments stated in this video are based on a presupposition that the materialist,reductionist view is undeniably correct, which at the the very least, to weigh in all the possibilities for the sake of objectivity, should be considered questionable and not to be taken for granted. The view of death from a frame that treats us as chemicals, physical reactions and biological selfish genes, in my humble opinion, leads to a dangerous view of the world that makes it not only bleak, but also void of meaning, purpose and design.

Before somebody accuses me of mumbo jumbo or verbal gymnastics let me say that we all feel deep inside us that we are not merely mechanistic, organic and clockwork-like in our shape and form. We have "feelings" which are not equivalent to the nervous system sending signals to our bodies.

These feelings of "longing", say for connecting to God, and having peaceful and purposeful path are for the very least an indication that we are "yearning" to be set free from the confinement of our temporal, 3D bodies. Let's not fall into the trap of what's similar to the Freudian interpretation of "love" as "sublimated sex", or loving for others what you love for yourself is impossible and has "ulterior" motives. I would like to emphasize again that this view is dangerous, it makes humans, well, not humans. What makes us different from other creatures is not only our intellect and reasoning capabilities. We are highly sentimental and emotional beings, not the emotional Vs logical false dichotomy. I mean emotions in the sense of: " we would like to see poverty go away so that people wouldn't suffer.

This goal is driven by a "feeling" that we want other people to be happy and prosperous, but no intelligent person in our wildest dreams would dare say (I hope so) that these feelings for others to be happy are merely genetic dispositions plus biological necessity (Yikes!), that's why our lives are becoming void of meaning and purpose because when goals are reduced to physical laws then how can we "feel" safe, tranquil and loved-- a psychologist would call that person a psychopath, I hope that we don't help in spreading this materialist view that pretentiously wears science to strip us from the value of feelings.

I know I talked a lot, and maybe some people won't like what I wrote, but I just wanted to stir the stagnant water.

Disclaimer: English is not my first language (Arabic is)

I don't feel like I am knowledgeable enough to argue against most of these philosophers. However, they did not make me think about death as something pleasant. They made me think that my life is irrelevant. That intelligent life is not the most unique thing in the universe. Of all of the amazing things the universe has, as far as we know, nothing, absolutely nothing gets even close to reason as we do. To be creative as we are. To wonder about ourselves and the reality we experience. Yet, despite being so incredibly unique, we are one of the most fragile and ephemeral things in the entire cosmos. This not only sounds absurd to me, but also as a waste of resources. Humans have a literally endless potential. The limitations on the span of our lives have caused us to simply think that brief existence is somehow better than an eternal one and find reasons to argue for it. Apart from people who want to end their pain or don't value their existence as the most important thing there is, we all want to live. Not necessarily forever, but we want to live. Having experiences and reacting to the world around is not always pleasant but it is much better than ceasing to exist together. I don't think these guys got to consider the very notion of not existing in a critical manner. It's not the end of pain, not the end of suffering. We feel pain now and death is not a savior. It's like the guy who watches you get beat up and then knocks you down with a pipe. Some people could argue that he relieved you from the pain, but isn't much more reasonable to think that he was just piling on on your suffering? And these people who say eternal life is boring or dangerous cannot really argue for death being a good thing, because they are doing the very thing to contradict their statement: living to say that death is good. I understand some people who argue that there is nothing we can do about it, so arguing is pointless. But people who say death is natural and we should welcome it, I do not understand. I love my life. With all the good and the bad, the one thing I wish to avoid more than anything is to stop existing. Hell, I would definitely abandon my morals, ethic or any sort of abstract belief for the certainty of living forever. I'd do anything to live for as long as I wanted and not just wither and die like I was nothing to begin with. Life is good. But with its end, it makes it nothing but a brief pleasure. An everlasting life would be perfect, because even if you did want to stop living, which I doubt most people would, you would still have the chance, you would have the freedom. And that's what death is. It enslaved us. And it has done such an amazing job, even the smartest people in the world don't dare to question it or fight against it. They just accept this horrible enemy as being a caring friend.

I'm not afraid of death so much as I am of dying horribly; when I see a precipice, I think of falling over, the momentary terror of free fall, and being splattered on the rocks below. I think of coming to awareness with my insides exposed for the world to see, I think of watching helplessly as animals come to scavenge my flesh. I think of running my tongue fruitlessly along my jaw, trying to find teeth still in their gums. I think of the panic of exposed bone and seeing parts of myself you should only see in anatomy lessons.

I'm terrified of the thought that I might be survived by my parents; I saw what my brother's death did to them, and wouldn't wish that on anyone.

And the thought of non-existence; though I realize I shouldn't be, for the reasons described. But suppose someone could erase your memory. Would you be cool with it if they wanted to erase the next 11 hours or so, so they could do some stuff to you and you wouldn't know? "What sort of stuff," you'd ask. "Doesn't matter, you won't remember it," they say. And that thought is terrifying. Erasure from existence is terrifying existentially.

I do not fear death, but I do believe it is unnecessary.  There is no reason to die.  We are the byproduct of an arms race between DNA, minds strapped to a biological substrate, dragged along by the molecule's method of evolution.  We are essentially being used by a natural process to improve the success of particular strands of deoxyribonucleic acid.  However, unlike our predecessors, we have the means to escape, to break our programming, to give our lives meaning beyond reproduction and transcend the biological bonds that hold us.  Already, we have nearly defeated its chief tool: natural selection.  Those poor people born with errors in their genetic code, failed experiments, can now live fulfilling lives.  With the number of scientific revolutions occurring (with CRISPR, quantum computing, etc.) I would not be surprised if we defeated natural death itself within the next 50-100 years.  We will use technology to remove biological disadvantage.  The mind will be improved to such an extent that its original predetermined composition will not mean much.  There will be no unintelligent people, only very powerful and unique minds.  Physical strength is already irrelevant, but it will become more so.  Everyone will be aesthetically beautiful according to their own tastes, making appearance an honest reflection of one's personality.  Of course, the expiration date will go as well.  We can only hope to be beneficiaries of this revolution, but, if we aren't, we can still contribute and guide the future down that path.

Epicurus was NOT a Stoic philosopher!
Stoicism and Epicureanism were the in many respects completely opposite each other in their view of how the 'Wise man' should live his life. Stoics (especially the late Roman Stoics - Seneca the Younger, Epictetus) mostly viewed Epicureans as professing a weakness of mind and body, serving the material of man, rather that the essential - the spirit (the idea that Good = 'feels good' would make a Stoic cringe, and it often did).
For anyone studying these ancient schools this distinction is essential.

I've had this little thought in my head for a while, and I thought this was a good place to share it.

It's a logical method for a basic form of reincarnation to exist.

Imagine the time before you were born. Of course you can;t. You didn't exist at all. You were dead, before you existed. Or at least, you were in exactly the same state of being as you would be, after you die.

Thus, it stands to reason that if you return to that same state that you spawned from in the first place, that it could happen again, and may have happened before. This doesn't imply any mystical past life memory retention, but it is a curious thought.

With that interesting note out of the way, I'm still holding out hope that Aubrey Degrey's SENS team pulls through and essentially cures aging (or more appropriately develops the treatments necessary to rejuvenate the damage caused by aging). Him, or Google's Calico division. Either one could possibly offer the currently young or middle aged alive now the chance to live forever. Or at least for far longer than the current average lifespan.

I don't think that most people have a fear of death, as much as they have fear of not surviving. Survival is deeply hardwired in our instincts because we were not supposed to live comfortably until we're 80. We were supposed to scrape through until we're 50 or younger. If we were any less inclined to live, we might as well have given up on working all day for food and shelter and running away from animals or protecting our infants. The reason death is a vastly different occasion to any other milestone is that death necessarily includes finality. A loved one dying means we never get to see them again, never feel their embrace or their touch, hear their laughter or look into their eyes. It is true that when a child moves away to college, we mourn somewhat because it is the end of an era, but ultimately we know that we can still see them, they are still on this Earthly plane and we can still be with them. Death affords no such luxury: it is not just the end of AN era, but the end of ALL eras with that person. We can celebrate someone's love and cherish them once they die, but we are still devastated at their absence, because it is the only way TO feel.

Yeah, sorry, but the annihilation of all my memories, thoughts, and emotions; the loss of all my family and friends for all of eternity; and the eventual death of all humans and the decay of every single human idea, story, or piece of art scares me. And it should. All people fear the death of their loved ones, at the very least. Even religious people cry when their family members die, even though they probably wouldn't cry if they'd simply moved away somewhere very nice. Every human on some level understands that death is a terrible final ending. Fearing death is like fearing a giant monster with claws and sharp teeth. It actually makes a good deal of sense, because death is basically the worst possible outcome. You say it's a tragedy when someone dies at 20, because they missed out on so much life. But if we could live for 200 years, dying at 80 would seem a terrible loss. It's only because we have to die so soon (currently) that we rationalize and pretend like it's okay; it's too hard to look at it straight in the face. And if some species never had to die at all, the existence of death itself would seem a deeply terrible tragedy, and that's exactly what it is. We only pretend otherwise because it's inevitable.
